article_title: Nearly 90,000 in San Antonio area sign up for health insurance
article_text:
Nearly 90,000 in San Antonio area sign up for health insurance 90,000 sign up locally in health care marketplace

Photo: Jerry Lara /San Antonio Express-News Oscar Soriano waits to sign up for health insurance during a...

The deadline to buy health insurance for 2015 is less than two weeks away, but almost 90,000 people in the San Antonio and New Braunfels area already have enrolled in health plans sold through the government-run marketplace, according to numbers released Wednesday.

article_metadata.description: The deadline to buy health insurance for 2015 is less than two weeks away, but almost 90,000 people in the San Antonio and New Braunfels area already have enrolled in health plans sold through the government-run marketplace, according to numbers released Wednesday.  [...] date, they won’t be able to buy health insurance unless they have special circumstances, such as losing employer-sponsored coverage, losing health benefits through a divorce or being denied Medicaid or Children’s Health Insurance Program benefits.  Nearly 970,000 Texans signed up for health plans through the marketplace as of Jan. 30, according to the latest data released Wednesday by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services — a figure surpassing last year’s statewide enrollment of 733,757 people.  “The data shows that we’re making significant progress all across America and certainly in Texas,” U.S. Department of Health and Human Services regional director Marjorie Petty said during a conference call with reporters Wednesday.  In the Austin and Round Rock metropolitan area, more than 85,000 people purchased 2015 health insurance plans through the federal marketplace, meaning that region lags slightly behind San Antonio and New Braunfels.  Consumers who don’t get health insurance in 2015 and don’t qualify for an exemption will have to pay a penalty when they file their tax returns next year — 2 percent of their annual household income or $325 per adult and $162.50 per child under 18 years old, whichever amount is greater.
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy O'Hare, Staff Writer
